The case revolves around the prosecution of the first respondent for allegedly breaching the terms of an award made by the Industrial Tribunal, Madras, on December 15, 1947. The respondent had failed to implement certain terms of the award, which were binding on him. The prosecution was based on the award, and the respondent raised a preliminary objection before the Magistrate, arguing that the award was ultra vires and void.

The respondent's contention was that the award was not binding on him, as the reference made to the Industrial Tribunal was not competent. The respondent argued that the reference was too vague and general, lacking specific details about the disputes or parties involved. The respondent also contended that the Government had an obligation to specify the disputes before making a reference under section 10(1) of the Act.

The court, however, did not hear arguments on the constitutional issue, as it considered that the contentions of the appellant on the first two points must prevail. The court ultimately did not address the constitutional issue, focusing instead on the merits of the case.

The final judgment of the case is that the appeal is allowed, and the order of the High Court is set aside. The first respondent's petition is dismissed.
